conversation.content: Um, wait, did we already, you know, cut the cake? I mean, I can't remember if we, er, did that part yet.
We haven't cut the cake yet, though I suppose it doesn't really matter since half the people have already left and the rest seem ready to follow them out the door.
Oh! The speeches! Did I give my speech?
You gave your speech twenty minutes ago, right after dropping your notes and before you forgot your cousin's name - it's all documented in the schedule that nobody's following anyway.
I should, uh, probably [yawn] find my notes again, you know, just in case I need to, well, say something else later.
Your notes are crumpled in the punch bowl where you left them, though I doubt anyone will ask for an encore performance given how the first one went.
The decorations look amazing! When did we put those up?
This morning at 6 AM, as planned, though three of the balloons have already popped and the banner's starting to sag on the left side, which seems fitting somehow.
Should we do the group photo now? Or did we do that?
We attempted it twice, but, hmm, people keep [laugh] wandering off, so, you know, we only have partial groups - honestly, it's like herding cats in a thunderstorm.
I forgot to thank the DJ! Is he still here?
The DJ left an hour ago, which is, um, actually [curious] concerning since, well, the music is still playing somehow - I guess he just left his laptop running on shuffle.
What about the gift table? Did someone move it?
Right.
So, wait, the gifts are, uh, still there? I mean, I should probably, you know, check on them or something.

They're exactly where they've been all day, though, er, I noticed someone's toddler was, basically, unwrapping them earlier - honestly, at this point it hardly matters since this whole event is slowly unraveling anyway.
Actually, I think I, um, left something important in the, well, kitchen? Or maybe it was, you know, the coat room?
Whatever you left is probably [shaky voice] gone by now, just like the extra champagne and half the centerpieces - people have been helping themselves to everything that isn't nailed down.
Oh! The thing is, we should, hmm, do the toast soon, right? I mean, before everyone, uh, leaves completely.
Most people are already gone or heading to their cars, but sure, we can toast to the empty chairs and wilting flowers - it seems appropriately symbolic for how everything eventually falls apart.
